data.title: 100 Beautiful Japanese Last Names: With Meanings
data.meta_description: Discover cool Japanese last names and learn their beautifully fascinating meanings, how to say them, and much more.
data.text:
Are you taking a trip to Tokyo and need to improve your pronunciation? Want to connect with your ancestry? Or perhaps youâ€™re simply curious about Japanese history and culture? Whatever your reason, itâ€™s a good idea to familiarize yourself with popular Japanese surnames.

Modern Japanese family names derive from Japanâ€™s previous clan system and are usually based on occupations or geographical descriptions.

Here, weâ€™ve composed an in-depth catalog of Japanese last names. With popularity statistics, famous namesakes, and a language lesson on each, our curated list will leave you feeling inspired and well-educated in no time. So letâ€™s dive right in!

100 Popular Japanese Last Names

Jump into our jam-packed list of 100 Japanese last names.

Abe

Abe combines the Japanese kanji â€œa,â€ written as å®‰ (peace), and â€œbe,â€ written as å€ (multiple times) or éƒ¨ (part/section). Abe derives from two Japanese clans, one of which descended from Prince ÅŒhiko. Abe also means â€œsun festivalâ€ in the Ainu language. In English, Abe (AYB) is short for Abraham, while the Frisian Abe (A-buh) is a diminutive of Adalbert.

Origin: Japanese, English, Frisian

Meaning: Many times peace, father of a multitude, noble

Pronunciation: A-BEH, AYB, A-buh

Namesakes: Toshiki Abe, a Japanese professional baseball player. Shinzo Abe, a Japanese politician, statesman, and former Japanese prime minister. Natsumi Abe, a Japanese singer, actress, and girl group member.

Popularity: Abe ranked in the top 25 surnames in Japan since 2008; in 2010, it was the 10,837th most common surname in the U.S.

Aikawa

Aikawa combines the Japanese kanji â€œaiâ€ written as ç›¸ (together/mutually) or æ„› (love/affection) and â€œkawaâ€ written as å· or æ²³ (river/stream). The anime BLEACH includes a character called Love or Rabu (RA-BOO) Aikawa. This is likely a play on the meaning of the surname. Ranking 574th in 2014, Aikawa is somewhat common among Japanese last names.

Origin: Japanese

Meaning: Love river, together stream

Pronunciation: EYE-ka-wa

Namesakes: Ryoji Aikawa, a Japanese former professional baseball player. Yoshisuke Aikawa, a Japanese entrepreneur, businessman, politician, and founder of the Nissan zaibatsu (Nissan Group).

Popularity: Aikawa is in the top 1,000 surnames in Japan, and in 2010, it placed 156,044th in the U.S.

Akabane

Akabane may have started as a nickname and is a neighborhood in Tokyoâ€™s Kita province. It combines the Japanese kanji èµ¤ â€œaka,â€ meaning â€œred,â€ and ç¾½ â€œhane,â€ meaning â€œfeather.â€ Since ã¯ã­ â€œhaneâ€ is an old dialect word for åŸ´ â€œhaniâ€ (clay), scholars think Akabane might translate to â€œred clay.â€ A popular fictional namesake is Karma Akabane from Assassination Classroom.

Meaning: Red feather, red wings

Pronunciation: A-KA-BA-NEH

Namesakes: Kenji Akabane, a Japanese voice actor. Shigeru Akabane, ring name Little Tokyo, a Japanese professional midget wrestler.

Popularity: Akabane is pretty uncommon but ranks within the top 1,000 surnames in Japan.

Akagi

Anime lovers might recognize this one from the manga and anime Akagi, featuring the protagonist Shigeru Akagi. Akagi is usually written with the Japanese kanji èµ¤æœ¨, meaning â€œred tree,â€ but may also pair èµ¤ â€œakaâ€ (red) with åŸ â€œcastleâ€ or æ¥ â€œfuture.â€ Akagi is also a village in Gunma Prefecture, home to a stratovolcano called Akagiyama (Mount Red Castle).

Origin: Japanese

Meaning: Red tree, red castle, red future

Pronunciation: A-KA-GEE

Namesakes: Norihiko Akagi, a Japanese politician. Kei Akagi, a Japanese-American jazz pianist. Kanji Akagi, a Japanese former sprinter.

Popularity: Akagi was the 56,588th most common surname in the U.S. in 2010 and remains in Japanâ€™s top 1,000 surnames.

Akamine

Akamine pairs the kanji èµ¤ â€œakaâ€ (red) and å¶º â€œmineâ€ (mountain peak/mountain ridge). As one of the most mountainous nations worldwide, Japanâ€™s sunrises sometimes give their peaks a red hue. Akamine likely stems from this picturesque scene. Itâ€™s fairly popular among Japanese surnames, ranking 1,226th. But youâ€™re more likely to hear about Akamine Station in Okinawa Prefecture.

Origin: Japanese

Meaning: Red (mountain) peak, red (mountain) ridge

Pronunciation: A-KA-MEE-NEH

Namesakes: JÃºlio Akamine, a Brazilian Catholic archbishop and the first of Japanese-Brazilian descent. Seiken Akamine, a Japanese politician. Shingo Akamine, a Japanese footballer.

Popularity: In 2010, Akamine was the 40,261st most popular surname in the U.S.

Akiyama

Akiyama is derived from a Japanese samurai kin group whose clan name, like many others, was based on a location. It combines the Japanese kanji ç§‹ â€œakiâ€ (autumn) and å±± â€œyamaâ€ (mountain/hill). This one mostly shows up in eastern and southern Japan. Another historical namesake includes Yoshifuru Akiyama, a general in the Imperial Japanese Army.

Origin: Japanese

Meaning: Autumn mountain

Pronunciation: A-KEE-YA-MA

Namesakes: Nobutomo Akiyama, a Japanese Sengoku-period samurai and one of the â€œTwenty-Four Generals of Takeda Shingen.â€ Akiyama Saneyuki, a Meiji-period Imperial Japanese Navy career officer.

Popularity: Akiyama is popular in Japan and is the 3,504th most common surname in the world.

Amano

Amano feels quite peaceful with its celestial meanings. Itâ€™s one of those popular Japanese family names youâ€™ll probably encounter if you ever visit Japan. Amano comes from a location and uses the kanji å¤© â€œamaâ€ (heaven) and é‡ â€œnoâ€ (field/wilderness/plain). As a feminine epithet, itâ€™s usually written as é›¨ â€œamaâ€ (rain) and ä¹ƒ â€œnoâ€ (possessive particle).

Origin: Japanese

Meaning: My rain, heavenly plain

Pronunciation: A-MA-NOH

Namesakes: Akira Amano, a Japanese manga artist noted for her Reborn! Series. Amano Takashige, a Japanese Sengoku-period samurai. Yoshitaka Amano, a Japanese visual artist, scenic and costume designer

Popularity: Amano usually ranks in the top 300 surnames in Japan, and as a given name, there are about 4,087 bearers worldwide.

Aoki

For those who know Japanese, Aoki may conjure lively images of greenery and nature. It pairs the kanji é’ â€œaoâ€ (blue/green) and æœ¨ â€œkiâ€ (tree/wood). Because the noun â€œaoâ€ uses the same character as the Chinese â€œqÄ«ng,â€ it can refer to blue or green depending on context. The usage of ç·‘ â€œmidoriâ€ for green is a modern development.

Origin: Japanese

Meaning: Green tree, blue tree

Pronunciation: A-OH-KEE

Namesakes: Hiroaki â€œRockyâ€ Aoki, a Japanese-American restaurateur, offshore powerboat racer, and amateur wrestler. Steven Aoki, a Japanese-American DJ, music producer, and son of â€œRockyâ€ Aoki.

Popularity: In 2008, Aoki was Japanâ€™s 39th most common surname and remains in the top 50.

Aoyama

Aoyama is derived from a clan name that describes a location. It pairs the kanji é’ â€œao,â€ historically used to describe blue or green, and å±± â€œyamaâ€ (mountain/hill). Beyond sports and applied sciences, Aoyama is associated with pioneering spirits. Mitsuko Thekla Maria, Countess of Coudenhove-Kalergi, born Mitsuko Aoyama, was one of Japanâ€™s first immigrants into Europe through her marriage.

Origin: Japanese

Meaning: Green mountain, blue mountain

Pronunciation: A-OH-YA-MA

Namesakes: Akira Aoyama, a Japanese civil engineer. Shuhei Aoyama, a former Grand Prix motorcycle racer. Shuko Aoyama, a Japanese professional tennis player.

Popularity: Aoyama usually falls in the top 300 surnames in Japan, making it popular. Itâ€™s also the 5,502nd most common surname worldwide.

Arima

Arima begins with the kanji â€œariâ€ æœ‰ or å­˜, meaning â€œhave, possesâ€ and â€œexist, believe, feel,â€ respectively. In Japanese, â€œRâ€ sounds like a cross between â€œLâ€ and â€œR.â€ â€œMaâ€ is written as é¦¬ (horse), æ‘© (chafe/polish/grind), éº» (flax/hemp/linen), or èˆ (dance). Trinidad and Tobago also has a borough called Arima, the Arawak word for â€œwater.â€

Origin: Japanese, Arawak

Meaning: Owns a horse, water

Pronunciation: A-REE-MA, uh-REE-muh

Namesakes: Ineko Arima, a Japanese film actress. Count Yoriyasu Arima, a Japanese politician. Akito Arima, a Japanese nuclear physicist and politician.

Popularity: As a given name, Arima has about 4,565 bearers internationally and is in Japanâ€™s top 1,000 surnames.

Asano

Asano is written with the kanji æµ… â€œasaâ€ (shallow) and é‡ â€œnoâ€ (field/wilderness/plain). It originates with the Asano clan, a samurai family from feudal Japan descended from the Minamoto clan. As a given name, it pairs with the kanji æ™¨ â€œasaâ€ (dawn/ daybreak/morning) and é‡ â€œnoâ€ (area). Still, Asano is more commonly used as a surname.

Origin: Japanese

Meaning: Shallow plain

Pronunciation: A-SA-NOH

Namesakes: Aiko Asano, a Japanese singer and actress. Katsuhito Asano, a Japanese politician. SÅichirÅ Asano, a Japanese businessman and founder of several companies.

Popularity: Asano falls just outside of Japanâ€™s top 100 surnames, and in 2010, it ranked the 40,800th most common surname in the U.S.

Chiba

Written as åƒè‘‰ â€œthousand leaf,â€ Chiba is derived from a samurai family. The Chiba clan was a branch of the Taira clan descended from Emperor Kanmu Heishi. This clan adopted the title of the area they moved into â€” present-day Chiba City, now known as Chiba Prefecture. Thus, Chiba is a habitational surname from an ancestral dwelling.

Origin: Japanese

Meaning: One thousand leaves

Pronunciation: CHEE-BA

Namesakes: Ginko Abukawa-Chiba, a Japanese Olympic and World Championship bronze-medalist in artistic gymnastics. Mone Chiba, an award-winning Japanese figure skater.

Popularity: Chiba has ranked in Japanâ€™s top 100 surnames since 2008.

Doi

Doi pairs the Japanese kanji åœŸ â€œdoâ€ (earth/soil) with the kanji for â€œi,â€ written as äº• (well/pit/mine shaft), å±… (sitting/being), or è‚¥ (manure/fertilizer). While the â€œearthen wellâ€ meaning is mainly used in Western Japan, â€œearth habitation (being)â€ is more common in the East. Doi (Ä‘á»i), meaning â€œlife,â€ seems to be a fairly popular Vietnamese gender-neutral epithet.

Origin: Japanese

Meaning: Earthen well

Pronunciation: DOH-EE

Namesakes: Takao Doi, a Japanese astronaut and engineer. Isami Doi, a Hawaiian-born Japanese-American printmaker and painter. Misaki Doi, a Japanese professional tennis player.

Popularity: Doi usually falls within Japanâ€™s top 200 surnames, making it fairly common.

Egawa

Egawa comes from a combination of the kanji æ±Ÿ â€œeâ€ (bay/inlet) and å· â€œkawaâ€ (river/stream). Hidetatsu Egawa is a historical namesake who left his mark on Japanese culture and architecture by bolstering Japanâ€™s coastal defenses in the 19th-century. Egawa is still reasonably popular among Japanese family names in modern times.

Origin: Japanese

Meaning: Inlet stream

Pronunciation: EH-GA-WA, EHY-GA-WA

Namesakes: Kosei Egawa, a Japanese bronze-medalist Paralympic swimmer. Atsushi Egawa, a Japanese cross-country skier. Yuki Egawa, a Japanese professional kickboxer.

Popularity: Egawa is usually in Japanâ€™s top 1,000 surnames, and in 2010, it placed 139,228th out of 162,253 surnames in the U.S.

Fujimori

Fujimori is a combination of the kanji è—¤ â€œfujiâ€ (wisteria) and æ£® â€œmoriâ€ (forest). As a first name, the kanji for â€œmoriâ€ may be rendered ç›› (heap/pile) or å®ˆ (protection). Itâ€™s sometimes used as a boyâ€™s name in Peru in honor of the former Peruvian president, Alberto Fujimori.

Origin: Japanese

Meaning: Wisteria forest

Pronunciation: FOO-ZHEE-MOH-REE, FOO-JEE-MOH-REE

Namesakes: Alberto Fujimori Inomoto, a Peruvian politician and former President of Peru. Natsuko Fujimori, a Japanese professional womenâ€™s shogi player. Shizuo Fujimori, a Japanese woodblock printmaker.

Popularity: Fujimori is pretty common, ranking in the top 1,000 surnames in Japan.

Fujimoto

Fujimoto combines the Japanese kanji è—¤ â€œfujiâ€ (wisteria) with æœ¬ â€œmotoâ€ (base/root/origin). Fujimoto is sometimes confused with the more popular Fujiwara. The bearers of Fujimoto likely did descend from the Fujiwara clan, as the â€œfujiâ€ (wisteria) portion of the surname suggests.

Origin: Japanese

Meaning: (One who lives) under the wisteria

Pronunciation: FOO-ZHEE-MOH-REE

Namesakes: Sou Fujimoto, a Japanese architect. Tsukasa Fujimoto, a Japanese professional wrestler and actress. Miki ShÅji, born Miki Fujimoto, a Japanese actress and J-pop idol.

Popularity: Fujimoto is common in Japan, but in 2008, it fell out of the top 100 surnames.

Fujioka

Fujioka is common in Japan and pairs the kanji è—¤ â€œfujiâ€ (wisteria) and å²¡ â€œokaâ€ (hill/ridge). Some have mistakenly implied a connection to Mount Fuji, but itâ€™s more likely related to the prominent Fujiwara clan of the Heian period. A popular anime namesake is Haruhi Fujioka, the protagonist of the Ouran High School Host Club manga and anime series.

Origin: Japanese

Meaning: Wisteria hill

Pronunciation: FOO-ZHEE-OH-KA

Namesakes: JÅ«kei Fujioka, a Japanese actor. Chihiro Fujioka, a Japanese video game designer, composer, and drummer. Shuhei Fujioka, a Japanese potter.

Popularity: Fujioka is most prevalent in Japan and is the 9,620th most common surname globally.

Fujiwara

Fujiwara is a combination of the kanji è—¤ â€œfujiâ€ (wisteria) and åŸ â€œwaraâ€ (field/plain/wilderness). The Fujiwara began as an influential clan of imperial regents who dominated the imperial court during the Heian period. The bearers of this surname are descendants of the clan, or in some cases, the surname may simply mean â€œFujiwara origin.â€

Origin: Japanese

Meaning: Wisteria field

Pronunciation: FOO-ZHEE-WA-RA

Namesakes: Fujiwara no Fuhito, an Asuka and Nara-period Japanese imperial court member. Norika Fujiwara, a Japanese beauty queen, model, and actress. Michiko Fujiwara, a Japanese nurse and politician.

Popularity: Fujiwara is often in the top 100 surnames in Japan, ranking 56th in 2008 and 1,724th worldwide.

Goda

Goda combines the kanji â€œgÅâ€ åˆ (connect/join) or éƒ· (village/hometown) and ç”° â€œtaâ€ (field/rice paddy). The Ghost in the Shell animeâ€™s antagonist, Kazundo GÅda, is a notable fictional namesake. Goda is also a Hungarian diminutive and a Germanic epithet from â€œGotâ€ (God). In Lithuanian, Goda comes from â€œgodÃ â€ (thought/dream/honor/respect/glory/to perceive).

Meaning: Connected rice paddies, appropriate peace

Pronunciation: GOH-DA, goo-DA

Haraguchi

Based on location, Haraguchi is a surname taken from a little-known locality in Kumamoto. Itâ€™s written with the kanji åŸ â€œharaâ€ (field/plain) and å£ â€œkuchiâ€ (mouth/entrance). Ranking 514th in Japan, Haraguchi is pretty popular among Japanese family names.

Origin: Japanese

Meaning: Mouth of the field

Pronunciation: HA-RA-GOO-CHEE

Namesakes: Kazuhiro Haraguchi, a Japanese politician. Genki Haraguchi, a Japanese professional football player. Kozo Haraguchi, a Japanese track and field athlete and former record holder.

Popularity: Haraguchi is most prevalent in Japan, ranking in the top 1,000 surnames.

Hasegawa

Although Hasegawa is written as é•·è°·å·, it uses a non-standard reading of the kanji é•·è°· (naga-tani). Hasegawa means â€œlong river valley.â€ Because there was a place in Nara Prefecture called Hase/Hatsuse (åˆç€¬), which is famous for its long valley, the pronunciation of é•·è°· (naga-tani) became â€œhaseâ€ through association. The last kanji in Hasegawa is å· â€œkawa,â€ meaning â€œriver, stream.â€

Origin: Japanese

Meaning: Long Valley River

Pronunciation: HA-SEH-GA-WA

Namesakes: Ariajasuru Hasegawa, a Japanese professional football player. Nobuhiko Hasegawa, a Japanese table tennis player with multiple World Championship and Asian Games gold, silver, and bronze medals.

Popularity: Hasegawa usually ranks in Japanâ€™s top 100 surnames and was 32nd in 2008.

Hayashi

Hayashi is a first name and surname, ranking 10,683rd out of 162,253 surnames in the U.S. in 2010. Itâ€™s normally written as æ— (forest/woods/thicket). It can refer to the â€œhayabusaâ€ (peregrine falcon) as a masculine moniker. Otherwise, itâ€™s written as ç”Ÿã‚„ã— (growth/cultivation) or used as a kanji for â€œshiâ€ å¿— (goal/aim/will) or å² (history).

Pronunciation: HEYE-A-SHEE, HA-YA-SHEE

Namesakes: Chiaki Hayashi, a Japanese businesswoman. Chushiro Hayashi, a Japanese astrophysicist. Eitetsu Hayashi, a Japanese musician known for his work with taiko (Japanese drums).

Popularity: Hayashi was the 19th most common Japanese surname in 2008.

Hidaka

Hidaka is primarily a Japanese surname from the kanji æ—¥ â€œhiâ€ (sun/day) and é«˜ â€œtakaâ€ (high/tall). As a Japanese masculine given name, it could also pair é™½ â€œhiâ€ (sun/light/male) with â€œdaka,â€ written as äº¬ (capital), å¤ (summer), ç©º (sky), é«˜ (tall), å¤© (heavens/imperial) or ç¤¾ (company/office/shrine). Many other kanji combinations are still possible.

Pronunciation: HEE-DA-KA, kHEE-DA-KA

Namesakes: Hatsuo Hidaka, a Japanese officer and ace fighter pilot in the Imperial Japanese Navy. Sumiko Hidaka, a Japanese film actress. Keita Hidaka, a Japanese football player.

Popularity: Hidaka is a common surname in Japan, ranking in its top 1,000.

Himura

Despite its rarity, Himura is famous in anime circles. The manga and anime Rurouni Kenshin features the protagonist Kenshin Himura. In My Hero Academia, Rei Todorokiâ€™s maiden name is Himura. Usually, Himura contains the kanji ç·‹ â€œhiâ€ (scarlet/dark red) and æ‘ â€œmuraâ€ (town/village). In Reiâ€™s case, itâ€™s written as æ°·å¢ â€œã²ã‚€ã‚‰â€ (ice collection/gathering).

Pronunciation: HEE-MOO-RA, kHEE-MOO-RA

Hino

Hino is both feisty and sweet. It derives from a noble family which descended from the Fujiwara clan. As a surname, it combines the kanji â€œhi,â€ written as æ—¥ (sun/day) or ç« (fire), and é‡ â€œnoâ€ (field/wilderness). The feminine epithet may instead pair the kanji æ—¥ â€œhiâ€ with ä¹ƒ â€œnoâ€ (possessive particle).

Origin: Japanese

Popularity: Hino falls just shy of the top 100 surnames in Japan.

Hirano

Hirano is written as å¹³é‡, combining the kanji å¹³ â€œhiraâ€ (flat/level) or (calm/peaceful) and é‡ â€œnoâ€ (field/wilderness). This kanji combination can also be read as Heiya (plain/flat land). The Hirano clan was a samurai family that produced Nagayasu Hirano, the 17th-century samurai retainer to the warlord Hideyoshi Toyotomi.

Pronunciation: HEE-RA-NO

Namesakes: Nagayasu Hirano, a Japanese Azuchi-Momoyama period samurai retainer. Ryoichi Hirano, a Japanese principal ballet dancer. Kouta Hirano, a Japanese manga artist notable for Hellsing.

Popularity: In 2008, Hirano was the 81st most popular surname in Japan and was 88th in 2014.

Honda

Honda is famous due to the Honda Motor Company, named after its founder. It comes from the Heian-period Honda clan, likely descended from the Fujiwara. Written as æœ¬ç”° (root rice field), it combines æœ¬ â€œhonâ€ (root/origin/source) and ç”° â€œtaâ€ (field/rice paddy). As the rarer given name, itâ€™s also written as å¤§æµ· â€œhondaâ€ (sea/ocean).

Origin: Japanese

Meaning: Original rice paddy

Pronunciation: HON-DAH

Namesakes: Chieko Honda, a Japanese actress and voice actress. Soichiro Honda, a Japanese engineer, industrialist, and founder of Honda Motor Company. IshirÅ Honda, a Japanese filmmaker.

Popularity: In 2014, Honda was ranked Japanâ€™s 73rd most common surname.

Hoshino

Hoshino pairs the Japanese kanji æ˜Ÿ â€œhoshiâ€ (star) with â€œnoâ€ written as ä¹ƒ (a possessive particle) or é‡ (area/field). Itâ€™s a habitational surname taken by the ShintÅ priests of the Atsuta Shrine. Notable namesakes for Hoshino include the Edo-period samurai and retainer of the Owari clan, Shigenori Hoshino (also known as Kanzaemon Hoshino). Hoshino is rarely a given name.

Origin: Japanese

Meaning: Field of stars, my star

Pronunciation: HOH-SHEE-NOH

Namesakes: Yukinobu Hoshino, a Japanese manga artist. Hidehiko â€œHideâ€ Hoshino, a Japanese musician and songwriter. Kazuyoshi Hoshino, a Japanese racecar driver and businessman.

Popularity: Hoshino fell just outside Japanâ€™s top 100 surnames in 2014, ranking 161st.

Igarashi

Igarashi combines the kanji äº”å â€œiâ€ (fifty), the (unwritten) subject marker ãŒ â€œga,â€ and åµ â€œarashiâ€ (storm). Also Romanized as Ikarashi or Isoarashi, it probably originated with the Ikarashi River and the legend of Ikatarashihiko-no-mikoto, who pioneered the region. Igarashi could stem from the Ainu â€œInkar-us-iâ€ (overlook-always doing-place). The Deadman Wonderland manga and anime feature the fictional namesake, Ganta Igarashi.

Origin: Japanese

Meaning: Fifty storms

Pronunciation: EE-GA-RA-SHEE

Variations: Ikarashi, Isoarashi

Namesakes: Aguri Igarashi, a Japanese manga artist. Hiroyuki Igarashi, stylized stage name HIRO, a Japanese dancer and producer. Kanoa Igarashi, a Japanese-American award-winning professional surfer.

Popularity: Although Igarashi is most popular in Japan, it falls short of the top 100 surnames there.

Ikeda

Ikeda stems from the description of a location. It started as a Japanese clan descended from the Seiwa Genji, a line of the Minamoto clan. Itâ€™s a combination of the kanji æ±  â€œikeâ€ (pool/pond) and ç”° â€œtaâ€ (field/rice paddy). Thus, it can mean â€œrice paddy near the lake/pond.â€

Origin: Japanese

Meaning: Rice paddies and pond, rice paddy near the pond

Pronunciation: EE-KEH-DA

Namesakes: Kikunae Ikeda, a Japanese chemist and university professor, who discovered and named the umami flavor. Fumiyo Ikeda, a Japanese dancer, actress, and choreographer.

Popularity: Ikeda was Japanâ€™s 26th most common surname in 2008 and 2014.

Imai

Imai comes from a location description and uses the kanji ä»Š â€œimaâ€ (now/present) and äº• â€œiâ€ (water well/mine shaft/pit). This can mean â€œnew place of residence,â€ but is usually written to mean â€œnew well.â€ Imai certainly feels fresh and upbeat.

Origin: Japanese

Meaning: New well, new residence

Pronunciation: EE-MA-EE, EE-MEYE

Namesakes: Nobuko Imai, a Japanese classical violinist. Eriko Imai, a Japanese pop singer, actress, and politician. Asami Imai, a Japanese voice actress and singer.

Popularity: Imai fell from 76th most common surname in Japan in 2008 to 79th in 2014.

Inaba

Inaba uses the kanji ç¨² â€œinaâ€ (rice plant) and è‘‰ â€œhaâ€ (leaf). This is one of those common Japanese family names with an unusual meaning, perhaps because it was once a nickname. Inaba eventually became a clan name. This samurai kin group, prominent during the Sengoku- and Edo-periods, descended from Emperor Kanmu through his son, Prince Iyo.

Origin: Japanese

Meaning: Leaf of the rice plant

Pronunciation: EE-NA-BA

Namesakes: Atsushi Inaba, a Japanese video game producer and the former CEO of Clover Studio. Koshi Inaba, a Japanese rock vocalist and musician. Akira Inaba, a Japanese professional shogi player.

Popularity: Inaba is in the top 1,000 Japanese surnames, and in 2010, it ranked 53,667th out of 162,253 surnames in the U.S.

Inoue

Inoue is topographic (describing an areaâ€™s physical features). It combines the Japanese kanji äº• â€œiâ€ (well/mine shaft/pit), the (unwritten) possessive marker ã® â€œno,â€ and ä¸Š â€œueâ€ (above/upper/top). This ultimately derives from the Inoue clan, descended from the Seiwa Genji line of the Minamoto clan. The Inoue clan consisted of the head family and two cadet branches.

Origin: Japanese

Meaning: Above the well

Pronunciation: EE-NOH-EH

Variations: Inouye

Namesakes: Alice Inoue, an American astrologer, author, and life coach from Hawaii. Junya Inoue, a Japanese manga artist known for his manga-turned-anime, Btooom!

Popularity: In 2008, Inoue was Japanâ€™s 16th most popular surname and 17th most common in 2014.

Ishida

Ishida is quite popular and is a commonplace name. It consists of the kanji çŸ³ â€œishiâ€ (stone) and ç”° â€œtaâ€ (field/rice paddy). In ancient times, the Ishida clan was famous for the samurai and military commander Mitsunari Ishida. In modern times, this surname is associated with the Japanese multinational food packing machinery company, Ishida Co., Ltd.

Origin: Japanese

Meaning: Stone rice field, rocky rice paddy

Pronunciation: EE-SHEE-DA, EESH-DA

Variations: Isida

Namesakes: HakyÅ Ishida, a Japanese haiku poet. Akira Ishida, a Japanese voice actor. Junichi Ishida, born TarÅ Ishida, a Japanese actor and TV personality.
